chapter.title: Welcome
chapter.para: jQuery is fast becoming a must-have skill for front-end developers. The purpose of this class is to give you an overview of the jQuery JavaScript library; at the end of the class, you should be able to complete basic tasks using jQuery, and have a solid basis from which to continue your learning.

This book contains more information than we can possibly cover during the class, and so it is meant as a references more than a syllabus. You’re encouraged to continue working through the information and exercises once the class is complete if you want to broaden your knowledge of jQuery.

This is a hands-on class. We will spend a bit of time covering a concept, and then you’ll have the chance to work on an exercise related to the concept. Some of the exercises may seem trivial; others may be downright daunting. In either case, there is no grade; the goal is simply to get you comfortable working your way through problems you’ll commonly be called upon to solve using jQuery. Example solutions to all of the exercises are included in the sample code.

section.title: Getting the Code
section.para: The code we’ll be using in this book is hosted in a repository on Github. You can download a .zip or .tar file of the code, then uncompress it to use it on your server. (If you’re git-inclined, you’re welcome to clone or fork the repository.)

section.title: Software
section.para: You'll want to have the following tools to make the most of the class:

listitem.para: For the Ajax portions: A local server (such as MAMP or WAMP), or an FTP or SSH client to access a remote server.

section.title: Adding JavaScript to Your Page
section.para: JavaScript can be included inline or by including an external file via a script tag. The order in which you include JavaScript is important: dependencies must be included before the script that depends on them.
For the sake of page performance, JavaScript should be included as close to the end of your HTML as is practical. Multiple JavaScript files should be combined for production use.

section.title: JavaScript Debugging
section.para: A debugging tool is essential for JavaScript development. Firefox provides a debugger via the Firebug extension; Safari and Chrome provide built-in consoles.

listitem.para: single- and multi-line editors for experimenting with JavaScript
an inspector for looking at the generated source of your page
a Network or Resources view, to examine network requests

section.para: When you are writing JavaScript code, you can use the following methods to send messages to the console:

listitem.para: console.log() for sending general log messages
console.dir() for logging a browseable object

section.para: Other console methods are also available, though they may differ from one browser to another. The consoles also provide the ability to set break points and watch expressions in your code for debugging purposes.

section.title: Conventions used in this book
section.para: Methods that can be called on jQuery objects will be referred to as $.fn.methodName. Methods that exist in the jQuery namespace but that cannot be called on jQuery objects will be referred to as $.methodName.
